https://youtu.be/MRRkb9pFQcM

I am rewriting my review for numerous reasons:

I'm at 14 hours now, and even after my initial bad review, I couldn't stop playing it. Let me preface this with - it's Early Access.

Have we all heard that phrase before? We sure have. Does it sometimes irritate us when we read someone use that as an excuse? Yup. But, this game is very polished in its current state - much more than other EA titles. That said, let's look at its pros/cons:

Pros     Variety - This game has a lot of things going on. Initially, you'll be confused (and I agree they need a better training manual or more quests to help us understand the various things), but eventually, you'll get the hang of it and realize you have so many different things to do that you don't have to do anything!

Performance - This game does have some hiccups, but 95% of the time, this game runs SMOOTH. Very smooth. In fact, the moment you hit 'play' (after you've created your character already), you'll be in the game in about 1 - 1 1/2 minutes, if that. It's fast, and EA, which means it's only going to get better from here.

Graphics - I've read people complaining about the graphics, but I have no issue with them whatsoever, and in fact, I rather like them. Nowadays, games are putting a lot of 'meat' into their graphics, which means if you aren't carrying around a 2,500.00 computer, you're getting lag spikes, choppiness, etc. But this game runs VERY well on the highest settings and I believe the graphics look great for that trade-off.

The Developers - When I initially complained about certain things, I thought the developers were going to get upset or defensive or whatever. But then they responded with understanding and support. They even admitted they realized there were issues with pricing schemes and other parts of the game. They then made it abundantly clear they will address those issues immediately and will build the game around the players wants/wishes. Don't believe me? Check out the discussion page and see for yourself. I've literally never seen that kind of response from a team before. That's definitely a 'pro'. If you want to feel like part of the creation process, then this is going to be the game for you to do just that.

Crafting - There is a lot going on with crafting. Do I like it all? No, but the concepts are unique (as far as games that I've played) and they add visuals and style to moving up in craftable items. That comes in the form of what they referred to as 'browser-based-like base building'. Basically, you build and upgrade various buildings that you use to create various items. These items are the bread'n'butter of your character's build. They will make or break you, so make sure you start working on that early, so that you get the hang of it (I will post YouTube videos in the very near future about how this is done).

Cons:
Keep in mind, the game is still EA and the developers are quick to respond.

Inventory - I've always loved loot. It's like Christmas with every group of mobs. But the inventory space definitely needs some work. There are a TON of things that you'll need for crafting, and access to the Warehouse inventory isn't convenient, so you'll find that 1/2 - 3/4 of your space is taken up with crafting materials you'll need throughout the game.

Quests - the quests definitely need some work. I'd like to have some audio with the quest windows, but there's none. They're also cumbersome and get old very fast. For some reason, I feel like I have to do all the quests in every game, and let me tell you - there are a LOT of quests, but they're largely the same type - go to 'x', get 'y', kill 'z'. But, it isn't all in one shot - it's go to 'x', come back. Go to 'z', come back. Kill 'y', come back. But again, you don't really 'have' to do the blue quests - you do have to do the yellow ones in order to progress past the first area, however.

Movement - This isn't so much a 'con' as it is a 'request'. There's no camera lock so that you can use your mouse to look around without having to hold down the right-click. I just wish that feature was there, but it isn't game-breaking at all.

Grammar - You will find many, MANY misspellings, typos, and fragments in the game. I'm somewhat of a grammar Nazi and I find my fork inching closer to my eye socket every time I find one. . .
Neither list is complete. There are a LOT of great things about the game and there are quite a few other frustrating things about the game. But it just released yesterday and is in Early Access. I do believe that with the dev team they have here, this game is going to become polished, community-driven, and will be a force among other bigger titles. Heck, I initially said 'no' to recommending the game, but then couldn't stop playing and ended up playing the game for 8 hours straight after writing the review. o.0

You know the game has something going for it when it keeps you sucked in to it for that long. I do suggest buying it, especially now when the price is low. Hopefully I'll see you in game! :)

So you are looking for a mmorpg to play. Possibly a sci fi one (We all know how few there are out there that don't involve you being a spaceship or a space marine).

Well my friend maybe this game will be for you.

The game centers on a conflict 200 years after WWIII in which Humans left earth to sleep off the whole Fallout world.
Within that time a race pops up all Space Elf style. They colonize and terraform earth whilst we sleep in some large orbit.

So now humans are invading their own home to get those space elves on out of there. Those space elves though...lemme tell you something. JRR Tolkien didn't design these guys and they carry laser blasters.. You won't find Sindarin here. No sir. Well maybe in a old book at the bottom of an ancient earth city long colonized by mutants.

So if that sounds about right for you continue on.

Trinium wars has many interesting concepts.

-Station: It's your base. It's your craft skills. If you ever played a base building game in a browser you should know what to expect. This is how you make sure your wants/needs are covered. Potions, skills,weapons,armor and MORE.

-Moba pvp: Yes this game has a fully functioning Moba within it.

But that's not your only pvp option.

There is a map shortly released upon which it's a 24/7 battle ground complete with mines and convoys to protect. As it's not been released yet I cannot judge this but the concept sounds about right.

It plays much like a old school rpg (L2, RFonline, Knight to an extent). In that regard they so far do not have the tropes of modern combat.....telegraphs etc and frankly? I'm glad. I have enough AMMORPG's to last a lifetime.

If you are going eh?" right now... I forgot a key thing.
Battles can be engaged in via tanks/flamethrower tanks/helicopters/mechs. I probably should of mentioned that really cool and epic feature but I saved it for last. Combat in pvp will be very much a vehicle war game as much as foot.
In a massive map...designed to keep up fighting all day.

The game does have it's faults however and that must be addressed.
The customization at character creation is sparse and the models of a few classes/genders do not scale well with the world.

Other gripes are ...

It is direct X9 which isn't very stable compared to 10-11 so thus no matter what they add it will always have that old look to it.

The UI: They are working on it and once it's "good" I'll remove this gripe but the UI is very much a miss.

The moba mode: Requires you to sit around in a lobby waiting on a game to start. (Currently we're asking for a new system to join games).

The old world meets new age isn't quite there. We need more city ruins etc

I usually take things at face value and I didn't start playing driven by high expectations, so I can't say I am dissapointed in a decisive manner by anything in particular.
One thing I AM dissapointed in (and yes, I realize I might be one of the very few people that see this as important), is the pretty abysmal state of proofreading and localization. This includes many instances where text isn't even translated and it appears in Chinese letters or creature names are poorly translated or even spelled out incorrectly. For example, an achievement text says I have to kill a rare spawn called a Behimos when in reality, the creature's name is something-something Behemoth.
Some may call this nitpicking and I am aware the game is still in development, but it's these little details that ruin the immersion. Plus if you don't understand what you have to do or are given incomplete or false instructions, what's the point really? The quest texts are already pretty thin as they are, they might as well be clearly formulated and spelled correctly.

On a lighter note, the game could really use an official wiki, but maybe that will come with time, as the player base will develop.

- Combat is decent

Cons:
- Poor translation at this point
- Only 2 races

- Quest dialog is very poor
- Pathing is slow and awkward for some of the quests
- Instancing of quests makes this feel more like a single player game
- My biggest complaint is the cash, which is very functional for an early access title that needs a lot of work. It is also pay to win. In order to use the best gear that drops you are forced to buy an item in the cash shop to identify it. Lower level items also need identifying though you can use in game currency to buy the items needed. Oh and did I mention you can buy in game currency with real coin?

For now it is a functional game that I am going to continue to explore and as such I will give it a thumbs up but at best 5/10. But beware the biggest issue being the cash shop which looks like you will need to spend on.

Early Access Review

Trinium Wars is a fairly stale and generic mmo, but it does have a few interesting features worth mentioning.  For the most part it's your average tab targeter where you run around killing x number of mobs and collecting y number of items.  The core gameplay is nothing we haven't seen a dozen times over.

The game does shine in a few areas though, and I can see promise occasionally.  The crafting system is interesting, at its core it's similar to the games you'd get on your phone or tablet.  Normally I ignore these style of games with disdain, but with the bulk of the gameplay occupying your time you never really feel you have to wait to continue playing.  I feel this is a pretty strong feature that would be worthy of more development time and focus.  If they build up a really strong crafting system it could make up for the lackluster gameplay.

Another promising feature is the use of vehicles in combat.  They were somewhat infrequent in the beginning, but you get a decent taste of what they have to offer early on.  I have a few issues with them (but hey, early access) but they could evolve into something interesting.

I glanced at the cash shop they had available.  While nothing stood out as overly pay to win, it seems a lot of quality of life features are locked behind a paywall.  It's too early to say how this will affect the gaming experience, but even early on I had some issue with the starting amount of inventory and warehouse slots.

Right now I would be wary of recommending this game.  There are too many good games already out with gameplay that overshadows Trinium Wars.  This could change if the developers play to their strengths and carve out a comfortable niche in the market.


*Keep in mind this is a initial impression of the game after about 4 hours of play and it's still in early access so things may be subject to change.

Hmmm what to say about TW?

So Ive been in game for about 10 hours so far ,and I have seen maybe 2 or 3 other ppl. The zones are completely dead. The combat is very slow , awkward,  and fidgity. Mounts cant jump lol really? Not a game breaker just annoying(No fall dmg though). In all honesty the game wouldnt be on par with other mmos even 10 years ago. Terrain looks ok but little to no character customization. So far ALL gear practically looks the same and offers no variance. Special Solo quest every other quest (in an mmo) is pretty annoying. Now as far as movement goes its pretty clumsy. No strafing while mounted and watching the pathing of escort npcs is just hidious. There are some cool features but not many. Only 3 classes , a warrior , ghost(rogue wanna be), and esper (think steampunk mage). All in all the game might have potential but with the playerbase being so low the game will more than likely die before it gets a chance to implement them. With other games likes Blade n Soul and Black Desert being just released sadly newer games like this literally stand no chance at gaining a playerbase .

No I would not recommend this game to others til there is alot more to offer class wise and content wise, and til there is actually a population in game.

Pros:
Low Spec pcs will have no trouble running on max
PvP (if population grows)
Early Mount
Achievements
Honestly thats all the positive things I could think of

Cons:
No playerbase
Poor character customization
Awkward and Wonky movement
Slow poorly animated combat animations
Generic Questing
Unique features game claims to offer poorly done
Cash Shop
Item prices ridiculously high to have no playerbase
Pretty Grind Heavy
Quest are story driven but offer a genericly poor story plot

I waited a long time for this game,but I came away dissapointed. First,the game boots into a low resolution that required me to change my font settings on my computer to 100% to get everything on the screen. The graphics are outdated,it looks like a game from 2002. The gameplay was nothing new,the same boring questing,kill x number of mobs,talk to this person etc.... One positive was the developer was active on the steam forum and helped me to get the game to run,which was nice. The game is average at best. There are better options out there
